titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the David Garrick Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday February 5, 2019 at 04:00
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Contains letters from Garrick to: James Stonhouse (regarding his first meeting with Hannah More), Edward Thompson, and Benjamin Victor; manuscripts of poems and epitaphs by Garrick; and a few manuscripts of poems by other people.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ongoing collection of documents acquired by gift and purchase from various sources. Type of accession (gift or purchase) and date of acquisition is noted in the box-and-folder list. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The David Garrick Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: David Garrick Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from previously existing cards in the Manuscripts Catalog, or from another inventory. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained. If the collection also contains unlisted or unsorted material, it has been noted in the box-and-folder list. This finding aid will be updated periodically to account for new materials that may be added to the collection. The date of the most recent update is noted on the title page. For information on material that may have been added since the last update, please consult the Public Service Desk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This finding aid encompasses accessions of single manuscripts and small groups of manuscripts and other papers, by or pertaining to David Garrick, which the library has chosen to group and list as an artificial collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Purchase, 1959.

did.unittitle: ALS to [Dorothy Savile Boyle], the Countess of Burlington, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Endorsed: "Mr. G. recd Oct. 1st."
Purchase, 1955.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift, 1958.

scopecontent.p: Purchase, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Accompanied by engraving of Garrick.

did.unittitle: Draft of letter to James Lacy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
With corrections and notes in an
unidentified hand.
Accompanied by a copy of the portrait
of Garrick by R. E. Pine in the
National Portrait Gallery.
Gift, 1940.

did.unittitle: LS to the countess of Rochfort

did.unittitle: ALS to Sir James Stonhouse, Hampton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Account of his first meeting with
Hannah More and detailed advice to
her regarding dramatic composition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift, 1958.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
With Garrick's seal in red wax.
From the collection of Dr. Max
Thorek, with his stamp.
Gift, 1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Purchase, 1957.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Dated "Monday night 10th."
Endorsed in an unidentified hand:
"Mr. Garrick to my father."
Purchase, 1961.

did.unittitle: "A Mademoiselle Fanni, Antoinette, Marie, Samarette de Raucour..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
On verso is "Reponse de Mons.
Villette." Two poems, holograph.
Copied but probably not composed by
Garrick. In French.
Purchase, 1955.

did.unittitle: "The Charrader's Recantation to Sir William Hamilton"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript poem of 5
stanzas, signed D. G.
Gift, 1937.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

play based on Dryden's "Cymon and
Iphigenia."
Gift, 1959.

did.unittitle: Epigram written on the publication of Doctor Johnson's Dictionary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift, 1979.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript poem of 8 lines.
First line: "Should ever discord or
disorder reign."
Gift, 1958.

did.unittitle: "Epilogue for L--- S--- After Playing the Character of Calista"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: "Epitaph for the Lord Spencer's Lopper, Topper, & Sweeper of Gardens"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript poem of 8 lines
signed "D. G." An epitaph for Thomas
Longford, Lord Spencer's servant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Poem, holograph.
Purchase, 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Manuscript poem of 10 lines in an
unidentified hand.
Gift, 1937.

did.unittitle: [The first thing is that thing without which I hold...]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript riddle of 8
lines. A copy of this riddle
(attributed to George Selwyn) was
sent by Horace Walpole to William
Mason in a letter of 1773 Jul 29. A
possible answer to the riddle is
"ribband box."
Gift, 1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript poem, signed
with initials.
Purchase, 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Holograph, four lines of verse, on
Sir Joshua Reynolds, from third
stanza of poem in The Public
Advertiser , 1777 Apr 29. With
clipping of entire poem and of
poem from preceding day to which this
is a reply.
Purchase, 1983.

did.unittitle: "An Invitation to Ld. Chatham Passing into Devonshire from Mr. Garrick"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Manuscript poem of 8 lines in an
unidentified hand.
Gift, 1937.

did.unittitle: "More Road Verses to the D: of Devonshire, Upon Her Leaving Her Muff & Sending Some Charming Lines to D: G:"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Manuscript poem of 8 lines in an
unidentified hand. On verso is
Garrick's "Road Verses Continued."
Gift, 1937.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript.
Gift, 1937.

did.unittitle: "Oh! For a Muse of Fire &c. to Tell"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Three alternative stanzas for "An Ode
Upon Dedicating a Building and
Erecting a Statue to Shakespeare, at
Stratford-upon-Avon". Not in
Garrick's hand.
Purchase, 1942.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Manuscript poem of 24 lines written
in an unidentified hand. Endorsed by
Garrick: "May for the Urn at
Batheaston."
Gift, 1958.

did.unittitle: Prologue for the benefit of the theatrical fund of the Drury Lane Theatre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Manuscript fragment of 14 lines in an

Gift, 1937.

did.unittitle: "Remarks (and Pretty Obvious Ones) on the 41st Letter"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript, with bookplate

of Eight Days Journey from Portsmouth
to Kingston Upon Thames by Jonas
Hanway (London, 1756).
Gift, 1959.

did.unittitle: "Road Verses to a Certain Bird, Who Endeavored to Pass Upon the Blackbird for a Sparrow"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Manuscript poem of 10 lines in an
unidentified hand. On verso is a poem
by Georgiana Cavendish, Duchess of
Devonshire, beginning "The blackbird
whose melodious throat..."
Gift, 1937.

did.unittitle: ['Tis true, as some say, that to death from our birth...]

did.unittitle: "Upon the Subscription to the New Rooms at Bath...by Mrs. F--Y"

scopecontent.p:
Autograph manuscript poem of 6 lines.
Written on an album leaf, signed

did.unittitle: "Upon the Two Justices - Foolding and Addlebraine"
